persons.name: Jean-JacquesRousseau
persons.description: Swiss born French philosopher who wrote, among other things, on social inequality and education. His ideas were used widely during the French Revolution.

persons.name: LuigiGalvani
persons.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

persons.name: AlessandroVolta
persons.description: Professor of experimental physics at the University of Pavia. At the end of the eighteenth century he Invented the Voltaic pile which produced electric current and which Davy shortly dubbed the battery. Davy described meeting him in 1814 in notebook 14/I, p.38. ForMemRSL.

persons.description: London surgeon and anatomist. FRSL.

persons.description: Founding editor of A Journal of Natural Philosophy, Chemistry, and the Arts (1797-1814) where Davy published some of his early papers. Part of the Godwin circle.

persons.description: German physician and natural philosopher.

persons.name: EdwardAsh
persons.description: Oxford trained physician and a friend of Rumford's whom he met in Italy. An Annual Subscriber to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

persons.description: Swiss mathematician who later worked in Berlin on electricity and also translated Hume into German.

places.name: Cornwall
places.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

persons.name: Jean-ClaudeDelamétherie
persons.description: French mineralogist and naturalist.

persons.name: GeorgesCuvier
persons.description: French naturalist and zoologist who was one of the founders of palaeontology. Perpetual Secretary of the first class of the Institut de France (Académie des Sciences), Davy met him when in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: ThomasBeddoes
persons.description: A politically radical (Jacobin) chemist and physician who in the 1790s established the Medical Pneumatic Institution in Bristol to investigate the physiological and possible curative effects of all the gases discovered during the eighteenth century. Between late 1798 and early 1801 he employed Davy as Superintendent of the Institution.

persons.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

persons.name: Antoine-Francois deFourcroy
persons.description: French chemist who collaborated with Lavoisier in standardising chemical nomenclature. Davy as a teenager read some of his work.

persons.name: Claude LouisBerthollet
persons.description: French Chemist. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: JohnKing
persons.description: Nicholas Johann Koenig, Bristol-based surgeon, painter and linguist, originally from Bern, Switzerland. A friend of Davy's in Bristol, King took his position at the Medical Pneumatic Institute after Davy left for London in 1801. King married Emmeline Egeworth in 1803.

persons.name: RobertBoyle
persons.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

persons.description: French analytical chemist. Author of the 1794 paper 'Researches on Prussian Blue', in which he first set down the law of definite proportions, or Proust's law, as it is commonly known.
